Award.AwardTitle: Using the Plant Heat Stress Response to Probe Genome-wide Regulatory Landscapes for Functional Relevance

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the molecular mechanisms that allow all organisms to respond appropriately to stressful high temperature. Understanding the mechanistic underpinnings of the so-called heat stress response has become a particularly pressing issue for agriculture given rising global temperatures and droughts. Therefore, this research will focus on plants. In addition to providing important scientific insights and enabling future crop applications, this project offers training opportunities for graduate and postdoctoral fellows in plant research. It also provides educational opportunities for undergraduate students who belong to underrepresented groups to study and conduct experiments within the vibrant environment of a major research university.

The heat stress response has been a model for gene regulation for almost a century because it is universally conserved, simple to control, and extremely well-studied. In preliminary studies in Arabidopsis thaliana, interrogation of the regulatory landscape during heat stress with DNaseI-seq revealed several unexpected findings, which this project will explore through two aims. First, additional DNaseI-seq experiments will be conducted to establish the generality of the earlier findings for physiologically relevant temperature conditions and to determine the connection between ambient temperature increases and acute heat stress. Second, chromosome conformation (Hi-C) analyses of normal and mutant plants will be used to determine how three-dimensional chromosome organization and specific histone variants contribute to the massive transcriptional changes observed in response to heat stress. The results are expected to lay the foundation for functional analysis of the regulatory elements responsible for thermotolerance in plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All living beings, plants, animals, fungi, and even human cells, experience high temperature stress in a similar manner. In response to heat shock, their cells highly and rapidly express a set of conserved proteins, so-called heat shock proteins, which protect other proteins from misfolding, thereby preventing cell death. Curiously, a mild heat stress induces some kind of “memory” such that it allows the subsequent survival of an otherwise lethal stress. This evolutionarily conserved phenomenon, named acquired thermotolerance, has been linked to the presence of the aforementioned heat shock proteins. In recent years, several studies have found evidence for the involvement of epigenetic phenomena, in particular certain histone modifications and special histone variants, in similar ‘memory’ phenomena. We used genome-scale analysis of the plant epigenetic landscape and histone variant mutants to dig deeper. Indeed, we found that the histone variant mutant in question was unable to maintain acquired thermotolerance as long as wild-type plants; however, subsequent experiments are more consistent with a lack of heat shock protein expression in this mutant than a lack of epigenetic memory. In addition, we were able to develop technology that allows probing for differential expression responses in plant cells in complex tissues. We envision that these experiments will someday soon pinpoint certain cells and regulatory elements which we can specifically manipulate to e.g. increase water and nutrient uptake in roots without affecting aerial plant parts and reducing plant fitness.
